On Jan 3, 2012, at 2:01 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:

>> The is no shared underst=
anding that the server needs to know about.
> 
> Of course there is - a ser=
ver has to establish a specific
> understanding of an incoming POST body to=
 a resource in order to
> process it in a specific way.

When was the last =
time you implemented a POST handler of a resource and thought in any way ab=
out what the client expects?

Answer: "never"; because it is completely up =
to the resource what to do upon POST.

What you call 'shared understanding'=
 is not shared (no obligation on the server) it is only an expectation the =
client has.

That expectation manifests itself by the particular choice of =
resource, yes - but the server knows nothing about that expectation nor doe=
s it care.

What I am trying to say: there is no contract layered on top of=
 HTTP that ensures successful interaction. Instead, REST deliberately lets =
go of that kind of coupling because it cannot be achieved in networked syst=
ems.

REST only makes explicit that the server cannot be guaranteed to adhe=
re to such a contract without introducing a level of coupling that makes it=
 impossible for the server to evolve without telling all clients up-front.
=

Jan
